description.plain:
The Chainsmokers are a New York City-based duo consisting of Andrew Taggart and Alex Pall. They write and produce their songs, and often feature guest vocalists.

The duo rose to fame with their 2014 viral hit, “#Selfie.” The Chainsmokers broke into the mainstream with their hit song “Roses” and their debut EP Bouquet.

In a March 2016 YouTube video, the duo talked about plans to release songs featuring their vocals. This was proven when “Closer” was released on July 2016 with Andrew Taggart as co-vocalist, alongside American singer-songwriter Halsey. “Closer” became both The Chainsmokers and Halsey’s most famous song.

2016 proved to be a breakout year for The Chainsmokers, with original songs “Don’t Let Me Down” and “Closer,” both certified platinum and headlining their sophomore EP Collage. The duo finished off their most successful year yet with three GRAMMY nominations, winning one GRAMMY for Best Dance Recording for “Don’t Let Me Down.”

Following their first GRAMMY win, the duo announced their debut LP, Memories…Do Not Open, on February 12, 2017 in a red carpet interview with Entertainment Weekly. The album was released on April 7, 2017, and was followed by a US tour titled “Memories: Do Not Open.”

The duo achieved further commercial success in 2017, with the releases of “Paris” and “Something Just Like This” helping The Chainsmokers tie The Beatles and the Bee Gees with three simultaneous songs on the Billboard Hot 100’s Top 10.

After going on a hiatus of releasing songs, the duo returned in January 2018 with the release of “Sick Boy”, the first single from their second album of the same name. The Chainsmokers' plan to build an album by releasing a song roughly every month was detailed in a Billboard article. The album spawned the minor hits of “This Feeling”, “Sick Boy”, “Side Effects”, and “Everybody Hates Me” which peaked at numbers 50, 65, 66, and 100, respectively, on the Billboard Hot 100.

The duo wasted no time in announcing their third album, World War Joy, along with their second arena tour set for the Fall of 2019. The first single off the album, “Who Do You Love” with Australian pop-rock group 5 Seconds of Summer became an instant hit, rising up the charts where it peaked at number 54 on the Hot 100 and was certified Platinum by the RIAA. The album also spawned two other hits in the form of the Platinum single “Call You Mine” with American singer/songwriter Bebe Rexha and the Gold single “Takeaway” with the American DJ/producer Illenium and featuring Nashville-based recording artist Lennon Stella, both of which charted on the Billboard Hot 100 at the number 56 and 69 spot, respectively. The album as a whole was released on December 6, 2019, debuting at #65 on the Billboard 200 albums chart and at #1 on the Billboard Top Dance/Electronic Albums chart, shipping 14,000 units in its first week.

On February 24, 2020 the duo announced they would be going on a social media hiatus to focus on the creation of their fourth, currently untitled studio album.

description.plain:
“Closer” is a millennial romance anthem that celebrates youth and heartbreak. It features vocals from singer-songwriter Halsey and Chainsmokers member Andrew Taggart, marking the first time the Chainsmokers feature their vocals on a track—Taggart previously performed backing vocals for the chorus of “Roses”. It is also their first collaboration with Halsey.

At the 2016 MTV VMAs, both the duo and Halsey performed “Closer”. The duo teased the performance as “new level” on Twitter. This was the second time that “Closer” was performed at Madison Square Garden — the first being at Halsey’s sold-out Badlands Tour show on August 13th, 2016 where The Chainsmokers performed as guests.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=agFMqNB9BYM

In September 2016, after “Closer” had already reached the summit of the Billboard Hot 100, Isaac Slade and Joe King, respectively the lead singer and guitarist of The Fray, were given additional songwriting credits on the song due to the similarity of its chorus to the verses of their 2005 breakout hit, “Over My Head (Cable Car).”

On the March-25-dated chart, “Closer” tied LeAnn Rimes Cibrian’s 32 week record in the Billboard Hot 100 top 10. The singer held it for 20 years – beginning December 13, 1997 – with her single “How Do I Live.” She congratulated the hitmaker duo on Twitter by singing a mashup of “Closer” and her own song.

On September 15, 2018, the song was certified Diamond by the RCAA, verifying that the song had sold an equivalent ten million units in the United States alone.

Related: How Blink 182’s “I Miss You” Inspired The Chainsmokers And Halsey’s “Closer”

description.plain:
“Paris” follows the metaphorical and literal journey of a millennial relationship; through youth and naïvety, heartbreak and mistakes, the two remain together, determined to endure the ‘ride’ and the hardships that come with it.

The Chainsmokers tweeted this prior to the release of the track:



The song features uncredited vocals from accomplished New York City singer-songwriter Emily Warren, and is the first original song of 2017 by The Chainsmokers, following a breakout year in 2016.

Warren’s involvement on the track was confirmed by The Chainsmokers' manager Adam Alpert to Billboard. The Chainsmokers hinted at Warren’s involvement in a tweet, and Warren also posted a video on Instagram saying it’s her vocals in the description. A followup interview with Billboard confirmed Warren as the mysterious female vocalist.

The song was first previewed in late December 2016 live appearances at SnowGlobe and the LACC. The Chainsmokers officially teased and verified the song through Facebook in early January 2017. The song was released on January 13, 2017.

The song made its official TV debut on SNL on April 8th 2017. The duo also performed their song, “Break Up Every Night” on the show.

description.plain:
“All We Know” is a relaxed song about a struggling relationship. The relationship in question is on the brink of falling apart, but a connection still exists through some sort of love and/or weed, and the lovers don’t know whether to keep the relationship going or not.

The song features vocals from LA-based singer-songwriter Phoebe Ryan, and is the fourth original song released in 2016 by The Chainsmokers, following the success of their #1 hit, “Closer.”

After previewing the song at various live appearances in late August, The Chainsmokers confirmed the song would be their next single in early September 2016. Phoebe Ryan teased it on her Twitter four days before and the YouTube audio was released one day before the song’s official release on September 30th.

description.plain:
“Roses,” featuring vocals by ROZES, is the third original song released in 2015 by The Chainsmokers, following “Let You Go” and “Good Intentions”. In an interview with BreatheHeavy, Alex and Drew of The Chainsmokers said the lighter production was a natural move:

This song represents an inherent change in the right direction not the beginning, but the end of that transition – almost like we have finally come full circle to a place musically we are finally completely happy with a song … That is not just a reflection us personally but also a reflection of us currently. That isn’t to say we won’t continue to evolve and take chances and the music will all sound the same, but this to us felt as natural as drinking the bottle of Patron every show. Roses is us, through and through.

It peaked at #6 on the Hot 100, becoming their highest charting hit until their #3 hit “Don’t Let Me Down.” It outpaced “#SELFIE”, which peaked out at #16.

This is Andrew Taggart’s first time providing vocals to one of The Chainsmokers' songs. He provides backing vocals to the chorus.

description.plain:
Returning to their trademark dance-pop sound after a fiery collaboration with NGHTMRE on “Save Yourself,” The Chainsmokers team up with country singer Kelsea Ballerini for their latest hit. The song also features frequent collaborator Emily Warren as a songwriter.

The track was first announced in an Instagram post five days prior to the release of the song.

description.plain:
Daya asks her boyfriend to save her and prove that the good boys don’t hide away.

“Don’t Let Me Down” is the first single The Chainsmokers released since their single “Roses”  achieved chart success. Andrew Taggart said of the track:

I’m super proud of it. I think it’s one of the best songs I’ve written and produced. I think people are going to be pretty blown away by it and it’s very different than “Roses”, which is nice.

The production is frantic and chord-heavy, with a final-drop switch up.

description.plain:
In “Sick Boy,” Andrew Taggart deals with the cultures of the East and West coasts of America and the self-doubt they cause in him. Unlike previous tracks, usually revolving around themes of love, this song combines a political stance with an ironic undertone.

The song features a new sound for the DJ duo, that sets it apart from past songs. Furthermore, it’s the first single release after the 2018 rebrand and their new sound, that started with the release of their debut album Memories…Do Not Open.

On May 10, 2017, the duo was interviewed by KISS FM Phoenix at their Memories: Do Not Open tour stop in Phoenix and revealed working on this track. When the hosts asked Andrew Taggart to give them a taste of the song, he said “They say that I’m a sick boy.” Taggart further described the track as being “angrier” and “darker” than their hit song with Coldplay “Something Just Like This.”

The New-York-City-based duo confirmed the title by tweeting it on May 31, 2017. On June 4, 2017, Taggart previewed a melody of the song on his Instagram Story.

description.plain:
“The One” is a ballad is about a neglectful romantic partner who’s too afraid to end their relationship.

The general theme of the song connects with several other songs on the album, mainly focusing on denying already dead-end relationships. All of them are personal stories that the writers have experienced, as Andrew Taggart told FaceCulture in an interview:

Some of [our songs are autobiographical], […] we write stories and we write songs of other people — really talented people — and sometimes it’s about us and sometimes it’s about them. How we start every songwriting session is “Okay, who’s got issues and wants to talk about them?” — we have a therapy session for an hour, two hours and we go from there, and then the song just builds up.

The Chainsmokers' debut album’s lead single is inspired by Taggart’s experience with feeling guilty about being absorbed in his work life and feeling like it would affect his relationships.

On the last day of rehearsal for their Memories…Do Not Open Tour, Alex Pall teased bits of the melody on Twitter. For the release of “The One,” Snapchat created a The-Chainsmokers-branded filter, that the duo promoted on Twitter.

body.plain:
“The One” is a ballad is about a neglectful romantic partner who’s too afraid to end their relationship.

The general theme of the song connects with several other songs on the album, mainly focusing on denying already dead-end relationships. All of them are personal stories that the writers have experienced, as Andrew Taggart told FaceCulture in an interview:

Some of [our songs are autobiographical], […] we write stories and we write songs of other people — really talented people — and sometimes it’s about us and sometimes it’s about them. How we start every songwriting session is “Okay, who’s got issues and wants to talk about them?” — we have a therapy session for an hour, two hours and we go from there, and then the song just builds up.

The Chainsmokers' debut album’s lead single is inspired by Taggart’s experience with feeling guilty about being absorbed in his work life and feeling like it would affect his relationships.

On the last day of rehearsal for their Memories…Do Not Open Tour, Alex Pall teased bits of the melody on Twitter. For the release of “The One,” Snapchat created a The-Chainsmokers-branded filter, that the duo promoted on Twitter.

description.plain:
“You Owe Me” was first played out on February 14, 2018, in London, the third stop on the duo’s month long European Memories…Do Not Open tour—in support of their namesake album. The duo teased it via twitter on the same day:

https://twitter.com/TheChainsmokers/status/963820158778298369

As has been the trend across recent releases for the group, the song once again features Drew Taggart on vocals.

The song leaked the same day it was unveiled, only a day before its official release.

description.plain:
The Chainsmokers continue their rebrand with another brooding single, “Everybody Hates Me.” The song focuses on the ironic and somewhat contradictory aspects of being famous as Taggart, the duo’s singer, laments feeling lonely and self-critical despite hordes of adoring fans. They began teasing the song in early March.

https://twitter.com/TheChainsmokers/status/971181775186792448?ref_src=twsrc%5Egoogle%7Ctwcamp%5Eserp%7Ctwgr%5Etweet

“Everybody Hates Me” is a continuation of the theme established in the duo’s 2018 releases, “Sick Boy” and “You Owe Me,” which tonally marks a significant shift from the group’s previous string of hits that primarily focussed on love and relationships, including “Closer,” “Something Just Like This,” and “Roses.”

The song, first played live on February 10, 2018, in Vienna—the first stop on the duo’s month-long tour of Europe in support of Memories…Do Not Open—was expected to drop during the first week of the duo’s tour. However, the duo released “You Owe Me” instead.

“Everybody Hates Me” was released on March 16th 2018, and was officially announced one day after the duo won three awards at the iHeartRadio Music Awards.

On April 2nd 2018, they released the official video directed by Rory Kramer, the duo’s good friend and tour photographer.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DKPCBAlDw2A

description.plain:
“Hope” is the 10th release off of The Chainsmokers' episodic second studio album, Sick Boy. The song was first teased on the duo’s Instagram story on December 11th and was released later that week on the 14th.

The song showcases a new sound for the duo as they continue to experiment with new sounds. The song puts a focus on Oak’s vocals, with a tropical house beat supplementing her voice. The song itself tells a story of a heartbroken lover, in a relationship that was bound to fail from the beginning.

description.plain:
“Young” is about remembering the break-up of a teenage relationship, but also the great moments they shared.

The song was previewed on Snapchat, before it was released on the duo’s debut LP Memories… Do Not Open. Taggart teased part of the song’s lyrics in a tweet:

https://twitter.com/drewtaggart/status/829063776095735808

The song was performed at the Billboard Music Awards 2017.

description.plain:
“Honest” follows a famous person’s internal conflict between hooking up with a girl they just met — who is interested in them for superficial reasons — and waiting until they get back to the person they love.

In their last rehearsal for the Memories…Do Not Open Tour, the duo teased part of the chorus in their Instagram Story.

description.plain:
“#Selfie” is a tongue-in-cheek, spoken-word dance-floor tune giving the peek into the night of a girl who likes selfies. With references to “Summertime Sadness” and Instagram, it’s likely to have a prominent fifteen minutes of fame.

The Oxford English Dictionary recently named “selfie” its 2013 Word of the Year, defined thus:


selfie noun, informal
(also selfy; plural selfies)

a photograph that one has taken of oneself, typically one taken with a smartphone or webcam and uploaded to a social media website


Oxford researchers even traced the first instance of the word to an Australian social media forum in 2002… how academic!

description.plain:
For the second track on their Bouquet EP, The Chainsmokers offer the emotive “New York City”, which details the story of a turbulent relationship in none other than the Big Apple.

The song features uncredited vocals from Victoria Zaro, who certainly plays a lot of shows in the city the song was inspired by.

https://twitter.com/Victoria_Zaro/status/657420386909495296

For the second track on their Bouquet EP, The Chainsmokers offer the emotive “New York City”, which details the story of a turbulent relationship in none other than the Big Apple.

The song features uncredited vocals from Victoria Zaro, who certainly plays a lot of shows in the city the song was inspired by.

https://twitter.com/Victoria_Zaro/status/657420386909495296

description.plain:
Returning to the lighter and more romantic style that first made them famous, The Chainsmokers deliver another summer anthem on “Side Effects”. Featuring pristine vocals from frequent collaborator Emily Warren over a beat that fuses future bass and tropical house, “Side Effects” tells a story of shedding any preconceived inhibitions to live in the moment and enjoying the fling mentioned in the song.

Originally teased by The Chainsmokers through a blank yellow post on their Instagram on July 19, 2018, the EDM/pop duo officially announced the song on July 23rd, updating their logo to a new and brighter design. After the release of the Sick Boy EP, which featured more thematically darker songs than was usual of The Chainsmokers, they announced in an Instagram comment on May 23rd about a new song that would flip the style on its head with a summer-ready beat.

description.plain:
“Break Up Every Night” is about a partner in a flawed relationship with the unshared desire for love.

Videographer and director of some music videos for The Chainsmokers, Rory Kramer asked Andrew Taggart to talk about the song at the Samsung 837 NYC Listening Party and he responded:

As you guys can tell the song is about dating someone who breaks your heart all the time, that’s super — loves you one day and not the next and I think we’ve definitely been there and this is a fun way to write about that. We have a lot of deeper cuts on the album, this is a more fun, up-beat record that talks about a moment of tension in the relationship.

The song was previewed on Snapchat, before it was released on the duo’s debut LP Memories…Do Not Open. The duo teased part of the song’s lyrics in a tweet:

https://twitter.com/TheChainsmokers/status/840023444565639168

The song made its live TV debut on SNL on April 8th 2017. The duo also performed hit single “Paris” on the show.

description.plain:
“Kanye” is the followup to The Chainsmokers' (in)famous viral hit, “#SELFIE”. Female duo Siren provides the vocals.

According to the Chainsmokers' Soundcloud, the song is less about Kanye West, and more about “being the person you want to be and not letting anyone take that from you”.

As Kanye said, ‘ I refuse to accept other people’s ideas of happiness for me. As if there’s a 'one size fits all’ standard for happiness.‘
This isn’t about him, or anything he has done, LETS BE VERY CLEAR ABOUT THAT! It’s about taking what Kanye idealistically represents and turning his name into an adjective. This song is about doing you, living life how you want to live it and not giving a fuck what anyone else thinks. Its about owning your shit and being happy with your life, no matter the circumstances, rich or poor, skinny or fat, young or old its about exuding confidence… and that’s what appeals to us so much about this song. So when you belt out 'I Wanna Be Like Kanye’ its not about him, but about being the person you want to be and not letting anyone take that from you.

description.plain:
“Bloodstream” follows a teenager getting disillusioned with the world around him by experiencing the bad sides of fame.

It was left off the original teaser of photos for The Chainsmokers' debut LP, Memories…Do Not Open, but was quickly added after the original posts were deleted and new versions surfaced with the missing song added to the list as the third track off the album.

Prior to the release of the album, The Chainsmokers used the chorus of this song as an alternate opening for “Paris” — a version which was titled “Paris: Bigger and Badder” — at their concerts. On January 4, the duo teased the chorus at the end of a Facebook video summarising Jingle Ball 2016. They teased parts of the first verse in a similar fashion and had Drew sing it at the end of a video of The Chainsmokers' tour series “‘That Time’ #33.”

American singer-songwriter Phoebe Ryan, who featured on The Chainsmokers' 2016 hit “All We Know,” provides very subtle background vocals to the chorus and alluded to her involvement by posting the tracklist on Instagram with a caption of:

📦 @thechainsmokers #BLOODSTREAM 📦

Furthermore, it’s the first collaboration with the UK-based producers and writers KIN and Mac & Phil.

description.plain:
“Push My Luck” is the sixth track released as part of the World War Joy album. As the second non-collaborative release of the album, it features a light guitar melody which leads up to a lively drop enriched with vocal chops.

Lyrically, the track is based on the dating stage of a potential relationship. One individual is feeling charmed by the other and wants to push their luck by trying to ensure that they will see each other the following day.

The track was first teased in May 2019, when The Chainsmokers shared a story on Instagram with the song playing in the background. A longer snippet was shared on September 25, 2019, with the full track being played live later that day at the opening show of their World War Joy tour in Cincinnati, Ohio.

description.plain:
“My Type” follows the thoughts of a lover doubting they know their partner, but still loving them, because they can’t control their own emotions.

It’s a song from New York City hitmakers The Chainsmokers' debut album “Memories…Do Not Open.” The song is expected to release as part of the album release on April 7, 2017 via Columbia Records and Disruptor Records.

“My Type” features vocals by multi-time collaborator Emily Warren. The Chainsmokers posted a snippet of the unreleased song to their Instagram Stories.

description.plain:
“Inside Out” is about loving someone, regardless of their faults and issues.

The song features vocals by Swedish artist CharLee, who co-wrote the track alongside Andrew Taggart, and is the second original song of 2016 by The Chainsmokers following the success of multi-platinum hit “Don’t Let Me Down”.

The song was released as a single on April 1, 2016 through Disruptor Records and Columbia Records. The track was later included as the fourth song on The Chainsmokers' second EP Collage.

The song was released as a single on April 1, 2016 through Disruptor Records and Columbia Records. The track was later included as the fourth song on The Chainsmokers' second EP Collage.

description.plain:
“It Won’t Kill Ya” is about a person seducing somebody by making small moves.

It’s a collaboration between the New York City-based hitmakers The Chainsmokers and the French singer-songwriter Louane Emera.

The collaboration was teased in late 2016, which created the false rumour Louane is the vocalist on their chart sensation “Paris.”
https://twitter.com/TheChainsmokers/status/781215668473466880

Shortly after the Memories…Do Not Open tracklist revelation, Louane tweeted the title and a possible line of this song:

description.plain:
“Kills You Slowly” is the second single of the year for The Chainsmokers, who are continuing their release schedule established last year, with Sick Boy. “Kills You Slowly” follows up the massive collaboration with 5 Seconds of Summer, “Who Do You Love,” and talks about a couple that is fighting and on edge, trying to salvage what’s left of a seemingly broken relationship. Both sides put on fake personas to do so, and try to hold in arguments, fights, and disagreements to please others, even if it does kill them slowly.

The song features a classic Chainsmokers guitar riff in the background but also has a down-beat trap influence with London on Da Track doing Misc. Production on the track.

The song was initially teased on March 21, 2019, when The Chainsmokers shared a video on their Instagram account featuring a recap of their tour in Australia and South Africa. At the end of the video, a snippet of the song is played. The release date was eventually revealed through an Instagram comment by The Chainsmokers:

description.plain:
“Don’t Say” is about a lover fed up with the mistakes the partner makes, wanting to end the relationship.

It’s a track from New York City production duo The Chainsmokers, and features vocals from fellow NYC native and multi-time collaborator Emily Warren. The song is the fourth track off the duo’s debut LP Memories…Do Not Open and is the first of two songs on the album that Warren features on.

Warren hinted at her involvement with The Chainsmokers' debut album in mid-January, 2017. On March 15, she confirmed the exact tracks she was involved in an Instagram post by saying,

i’m beyond excited to say i wrote & am singing on “Don’t Say”, & “My Type”, and wrote on “The One” and “Wake Up Alone” ft. @jheneaiko

description.plain:
“Last Day Alive” is about a teenager enjoying his life to the fullest, pretending he will die tomorrow.

The track features American country music duo Florida Georgia Line, the first collaboration between the two groups, and is the first divergence into country music for American production duo, The Chainsmokers. The lyrics were co-written by Dan Reynolds of Imagine Dragons. The song is the twelfth and last track off The Chainsmokers' debut studio album Memories…Do Not Open.

Part of the chorus' lyrics was teased by the production duo back in mid-December 2016 through a tweet:

https://twitter.com/thechainsmokers/status/810422651227250688

description.plain:
“Do You Mean” is the third single and second collaborative project that The Chainsmokers have released as a part of the World War Joy album.

The song features both Ty Dolla $ign and bülow as vocalists, along with Chainsmoker Drew Taggart.
The song features Taggart and bülow exchanging verses, portraying an argument between a couple about what they are saying and what they have said in the past. Ty Dolla provides the vocals for the Chorus and Pre-Chorus, to supplement the central idea of losing hope in others through the words that they say.

description.plain:
“Wake Up Alone” is an electro-pop ballad from the debut studio album by The Chainsmokers. Lyrically the track tells the story of a famous person, who desires a lover that will love them for their personality and not for the perks of being famous. It talks about the superficial and materialistic nature of many Hollywood relationships.

The song features plush vocals by R&B singer Jhene Aiko and it marks the first collaboration between the DJ Duo and Aiko.

description.plain:
“The Reaper” is the lead song of World War Joy, the third album released by The Chainsmokers. The song features Australian singer Amy Shark providing vocals in an ominous-sounding track. Drew sings about a person with two sides, one being pretty and one being terrifying. He’s conflicted about her, wonder if he’ll get her bad side, but also trying to prove himself to her by “pulling the trigger.”

The Chainsmokers and Amy Shark had been reported to have been working together in August 2017, with this track appearing to be the result.

The lyric video for this song is composed of different fonts and styles from well-known films, most of them terror films.

description.plain:
“P.S. I Hope You’re Happy” is the first collaboration between American electronic music duo The Chainsmokers and pop-punk band blink-182.

The track touches on a person reminiscing over a relationship that they aren’t quite over yet. The person doesn’t have hard feeling for their ex, and wishes them the best in the future.

The track was first debuted at The Forum in Los Angeles on November 26, 2019, on the North American leg of the World War Joy tour. The track had been teased back in January 2019 and has seen multiple other teasers posted on Instagram Stories since.

description.plain:
“See the Way” is a collaborative project between The Chainsmokers and Sabrina Claudio featured on the World War Joy album.

The song touches on two sides of a relationship where both people are trying to get over each other.  Drew talks about how his emotions are all over the place and tries to solve his problems with hookups with new people.

Claudio tries to cope with the break up by deleting their photos together and trying to forget about the whole thing. In the end, the two still feel the same about each other, and that it only took distance for them to realize it.

description.plain:
“Waterbed” is a single from EDM duo The Chainsmokers. It’s their second collab with Waterbed. It’s the beginning of a release schedule to drop one song a month.

The song uses its title as an unusual simile for twerking. The title was likely based on Waterbed’s name, like how “Roses” was based on the stage name of ROZES.

description.plain:
In a return to the romantic dance-pop style that first made them famous on hits such as “Closer” and “Paris”, The Chainsmokers tell a story of falling in love over a tropical-inspired beat.

The song was first announced via an Instagram post on November 14th, 2018 revealing a short clip of the song featuring Taggart. They officially announced the song on the 15th in an Instagram post teasing the song as well as showcasing the cover art.

The song is both a stylistic and lyrical return to form for the duo, after a series of singles that diverged from their established sound. In addition, the song’s light-hearted lyrical tone stands in contrast to the darker and more introspective themes of the year’s earlier songs such as “Sick Boy” and “Siren”.

description.plain:
Wiz Khalifa performed a live remix of The Chainsmokers‘ huge 2016 hit “Closer” when he took the stage at Okeechobee Music & Arts Festival on March 4, 2017. On March 17, Wiz uploaded an official studio remix of the track to his SoundCloud account.

The song’s original production remains intact, but Khalifa adds new bars with a verse and a brand new Pre-Chorus to uplift the crowd with an energy booster.

description.plain:
“In My Head” is a collaboration between American EDM-Pop duo The Chainsmokers and  singer-songwriter-rapper Juice WRLD. It was leaked along with 35 other songs from the Illinois rapper, recently famous for his hit “Lucid Dreams” which is off his third mix tape JuiceWRLD 9 9 9 and his debut studio album Goodbye & Good Riddance.

Billboard confirmed that the song is a legitimate collaboration between the two artists. It is unknown when the track will come out.

Propelled mainly by The Chainsmokers' trademark electronic piano-synth chords and Andrew Taggart’s vocals on the hook, “In My Head” continues The Chainsmokers' recent exploration of a darker and more personal theme in their songs, as showcased in the four tracks on the Sick Boy – EP, which was released on April 20, 2018. Sharing a theme recurrent in Juice WRLD’s music, he was an apt addition to this track given The Chainsmokers' recent transition to a more brooding and introspective style of their trademark dance-pop sound.

description.plain:
“Good Intentions” is a dance pop track powered by rock vocals about having the best intentions but ultimately making mistakes and failing.

The track was the second original song released in 2015 by The Chainsmokers, and features vocals from British artist Andrew Bullimore under his stage name, BullySongs.

description.plain:
“Make Me” is an unreleased song by American electronic music duo The Chainsmokers, featuring vocals from singer Jodi Gold.

The song, though it is has never been teased or announced, appears on ASCAP’s database.



It appears to be a more recent song, being listed under The Chainsmokers' own label Nice Hair and Sony, to whom they are currently signed.

description.plain:
“Who Do You Love” is the first single released by The Chainsmokers following the release of their second studio album Sick Boy and features the Australian pop-punk band 5 Seconds of Summer. The song features more pop-driven production than many of their recent songs, incorporating future bass elements that harken back to their earlier hits.

The Chainsmokers shared a post on their Instagram two days before the release of “Who Do You Love” with the caption:

3 years ago today we released Dont Let Me Down! This was our first time playing it in NYC on New Years and this is the exact moment we realized we had something special! This song changed the entire way we approach music and our lives! This Thursday we got another song coming that might do the exact same

description.plain:
“Closer (Shaun Frank Remix)” is the second remix of the multi-platinum hit on the Closer (Remixes) pack by The Chainsmokers, which was released on September 23, 2016.

The remixer, Shaun Frank, was one of the co-writers for the original song.

description.plain:
The Chainsmokers premiered this live cover on their Memories…Do Not Open tour through Europe.

To introduce it, the band’s drummer Matt McGuire performs a solo with burning drum sticks and Alex Pall challenges Andrew Taggart to do something as impressive.

The song was uploaded to social media on February 28, 2017, but not officially released.

The duo admitted on Instagram that this version is based on Skrillex’s remix of Kendrick Lamar’s “Humble.”

description.plain:
American DJ and production duo The Chainsmokers will release a new song on the 20th of April, 2018.

It will be their fourth release of the year, following “Sick Boy”, “You Owe Me”, and “Everybody Hates Me”.  It will also be their first song in 2018 to have a featured artist, as revealed in a post to Reddit.

songs.lyrics: Can’t afford to lose myself trying to be somebody else

description.plain:
‘Closer’ is a song from ‘The Chainsmokers’, which originally was a feature with Camila Cabello but she rejected it because she was still on the girl band ‘Fifth Harmony’ and they were about to put out an album out. After she rejected it, it was given to Halsey.

A little snippet filmed while The Chainsmokers were producing the song leaked where Camila was singing the chorus.

description.plain:
“Polkadots” was released by The Chainsmokers' as a free download on August 25, 2014 following the success of “Kanye.”
Similar to their second single – “The Rookie,” “Polkadots” is a dubstep track where The Chainsmokers tell people Polka dots are cool and trendy and everyone should wear them.

description.plain:
This is an annotated chart history of American production duo The Chainsmokers, based off Billboard Hot 100 chart history. It features all of their charting songs (including shared artist collaborations).

Note that songs are sorted by the year they peaked in, not in their year of release. For example, “Roses” was released in 2015, but didn’t reach its peak until 2016, so it is listed under that year.

description.plain:
In the Botnek Remix of “#SELFIE” the girl who loves to take selfies to asked to “shut the f*** up” and stop taking selfies.
Don’t get obsessed with taking selfies continuously!
